titleStmt.title: Tamil Grammar (in French) by La Lane

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

summary.p: BnF Indien 189 (ex- Tamoul 189), entitled Grammaire pour apprendre la langue Tamoul Ditte Vulgairement le Malabar on its title page (U1, p. 1) consists in 28 paper leaves (U2, that is, 56 pages) bound in one volume (260 x 200 mm). An unfoliated folio comes first, bearing the title-page on the recto (U1, p. 1) and a preface (“Préface”) on the verso (U1, p. 2). 26 folios follow (U2), all paginated except for p. 52.
The original pagination appears on the upper left corner of the page on the verso of folio and on the upper right corner on the recto. Finally, there is a back guard leaf (u1).

This manuscript is a grammar of Tamil written in French organized into three sections, each one with a different number of chapters. The first section includes 2 chapters, the second section includes 5 chapters, and the third section is made of 1 chapter.

The first section, Premiere Partie. Des Lettres de l’Alphabet Tamoul [First part. On the letters of the Tamil Alphabet] (U2, p. 1–p. 9) includes 2 chapters, which describe Tamil vowels and consonants, while a short preface (U1, p. 2), describing the extension of the geographical area where the Tamil language is spoken, precedes it on the verso of the front unfoliated folio. The two chapters are:

list.item: Chapitre 1er Des Voyelles des Tamouls [1st Chapter 1st. On the vowels of the Tamils] (U2, p. 2).
Chapitre 2e Des Consonnes des Tamouls [2nd Chapter 2nd. On the consonants of the Tamils] (U2, p. 2-p. 9).

summary.p: The second section, Seconde Partie (U2, p. 9–p. 39) is divided into five chapters, as follows:

list.item: Chapitre 1er Des Noms Tamouls [1st Chapter. On Tamil nouns] (U2, p. 9–p. 14).

summary.p: Nouns are classified into five different declensions: the first one for nouns ending in –am; the second for masculine nouns ending in –an and –en; the third for nouns ending in –ṭu and –ṟu; the fourth for non-masculine nouns ending in ṉ, l, ḷ, r; and the fifth for nouns ending in vowel with the exception of those already included in the third class.

list.item: Chapitre 2e. Des Pronoms [2nd Chapter. On pronouns] (U2, p. 15–p. 18).

summary.p: It differentiates between personal, interrogative, demonstrative, and some other types of pronouns.

list.item: Chapitre 3e. Des Numeraux [3rd Chapter. On numerals] (U2, p. 18–p. 20).
Chapitre 4e. Des adverbes Tamouls [4th Chapter. On Tamil adverbs] (U2, p. 21).
Chapitre 5e. Des Verbes Tamouls [5th Chapter. On Tamil Verbs] (U2, p. 21–p. 39).

summary.p: In the first paragraph (U2, p. 22–p. 27) the verb is conjugated into four modes (Indicative, Imperative, Optative, and Subjunctive) and four tenses (present, imperfect preterite, perfect preterite, future). It also discusses conditional, infinitive, gerund, preterite verbal participle, and passive. The second paragraph (U2, p. 28–p. 37) groups verbs into seven classes, on the base of the formation of the past and future tenses. It further discusses impersonal and the verbal infinitive, as well as the defective verbs (U2, p. 37–p. 39).

The third and final section, Troisième Partie (U2, p. 40–p. 52) consists in only one chapter which focuses on syntax: Chapitre 1er. De quelques Regles de Concordance et de syntaxe absolument necessaires pour entrer dans la Genie de la langue Tamoul [On a few rules about the concordance and the syntax which are absolutely necessary for entering in the genius of the Tamil language].

Cabaton in his Catalogue sommaire (1912, p. 31) describes the manuscript as follows:
Grammaire tamoule, par le P. de La Lave, S. J. 1728. Papier. 92 pages, 240 x 180 mm. (Ancien fonds, n° CCVII).A later hand corrected this information in blue ink.
Indeed, the manuscript is mentioned in the “ancient fonds” under n° CCVII (cf. Catalogus codicum manuscriptorum bibliothecae regiae. Tomus primus. Pars prima, complectens codices manuscriptos orientales, 1739, p. 444, no. CCVII), which states: Codex chartaceus. Ibi continetur liber Grammaticus inscriptus Grammaire pour apprendre la language Tamoul, dite vulgairement le Malabar, ou la langue Malabare. Lingua est peninsulæ Indicæ à promontorio Comorino usque ad gradum latitudinis septentrionalis decimum quartum. Alia tamen in regno Maissour, sed parùm diversa, usurpatur. Hujusce operis auctor unus è Missionariis Gallis Societatis Jesu. Anno 1728.
This grammar appears to be the work of Father Pierre de La Lane (1699-1746), who was posted in Tarkolam probably between 1705 and 1708, without remaining for a long time in India (Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1992; Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1995: 9).
Like Cabaton, Vinson wrongly writes the name of Father La Lane as La Lave, in the proofreadings of his unpublished catalogue (1868, p. 46) and in his handwritten catalogue (BnF INDIEN 1062, folio 66r), which states:
“Grammaire pour apprendre la langue tamoul, ditte vulgairement le Malabar”. à la fin: “faitte à Pondichéry et achevée le 18 novembre 1728, par un missionaire de la compagnie de Jésus de la mission du Carnat". Papier. Pet. In-4° – 92 p. – ancien fonds, n° CCVII. Une note d’Anquetil dit que l’auteur de cette grammaire est le père de la Lave.
The note by Anquetil-Duperron, referred to above by Vinson, is found in the manuscript BnF Indien 219, page 432, lines 1-3. Anquetil-Duperron (1808, p. 669) mentions La Lane’s manuscript – along with others, such as the Tamil-Portuguese and the Portuguese-Tamil dictionaries, and Beschi’s Grammar, in his letter to Cœurdoux sent from Paris on the 28th July 1768.

support.p: The type of paper is “laid” paper. It is thin, and the pulp touches the wires, making a latticework pattern easily seen when the leaf is held against a light. The paper has a watermark. See Muru (2019, fig. 6 ). Unlike in this back guard leaf, it is found, throughout the manuscript, in the centre at the place of the binding.

collation.desc: 1 folio = 2 pages = Title Page & Preface. No pagination.
26 folios = 52 pages = Text. Pagination 1-51, 52. 13 bifolios. No missing folios.
1 folio = 2 pages = back guard leaf. Blank recto verso.

supportDesc.foliation: Arabic pagination for U2, right or left upper side of each page, except page 52.
supportDesc.condition: Very good state of preservation and very legible.

layoutDesc.layout: Number of lines per folio/page: from a minimum of 13 text lines + 8 title lines per page (where titles written in different font sizes) up to 43 lines per page. The most recurrent number of lines per page/folio is 36/37. Only the first and the second chapters of the second section are layed-out into two columns marked in red ink. The formatting of the text reveals that the grammar was composed for the public rather than for personal use. In fact, the page layout delimits a writing surface between the right (25 mm), left (20 mm), upper (25 mm), and bottom margins (15 mm). Any mistake is corrected by posting a piece of paper bearing the correct version. Muru (2019, fig. 5).

handNote.desc: Black ink for the main text, red ink for marking the layout of the page (margins), rows, and columns in the chart.

decoNote.desc: There are no illustrations, no diagrams, but different sizes for fonts for marking title, subtitles, paragraphs, beginning and ending of text. There is one chart for Tamil letters spread on several pages (p. 2, p. 5-p. 8).

binding.p: The volume is made of 3 quires of which, the first is a quinternion (V), the second and the third are quaternion (IV): 1 V (ff. 20) + 2 IV (ff. 16). The stiff covers (boards) at the front and back of the book are attached to the quires by the cords which are secured by means of channelling. Damp leather, which is folded over the edges of the boards forming a turn-ins and glued down, covers the boards and the spine. Pastedowns of the initial and final bifolio onto the inside of the board conceal this configuration (binding and channelling).

origin.origDate: The copying of the grammar was completed on the 18th November 1728 in Pondicherry. See colophon (U2, p. [52].

provenance.p: The manuscript was sent in 1729 to the Bibliothèque du Roy by the Jesuit Fathers of the Carnatic mission. It appears in the list provided in H. Omont (1902), Missions archéologiques françaises en Orient aux XVIIe et XVIIIe siècles. Partie 2, p. 1188.

acquisition.p: The stamp on the first and on the last page of the document seems to suggest that the manuscript entered in the Library not earlier than July 1830 or January 1831 (cf. Pierre Josserand et Jean Bruno, Les estampilles du Département des imprimés de la Bibliothèque nationale, in Mélanges d'histoire du livre et des bibliothèques offerts à Monsieur Frantz Calot, Paris, Librairie d’Argences 1960, p. 261-298.)
